title: "unspecified error, please check the logs for more information" Mac Patcher not opening
body:
I have tried every solution that has been given to me under the Sun and also the ones that I had to dig really deep for. These are the specs for my Mac and the bug has only started since patch 5.2. Also when I open the patcher through Open package contents/contents/LoL/RADS/projects/lol_patcher/releases/0.0.0.19/deploy/LoLPatcher or LoLPatcherUx or LoLPatcherUxHelper the patcher opens for about 10 seconds and then quits after not showing anything apart from the basic GUI

Mac Version: 10.10.2 Macbook Pro (13 inch mid 2009) 
CPU: Intel core 2 duo 
GPU: NVIDIA GeForce 9400M 
Ram: 8GB (1067 MHz DDR3)

Every now and again it will open and I believe that the reason I can't open my patcher (which means I then can't open my client) is because for some reason my internet (TPG unlimited) can't connect to the OCE servers even though I live in Brisbane QLD which really should be able to connect to OCE but still just won't. Please help I just want to play after spending about $500 on this game.

replies.body:
TPG has a terrible reputation with Riot. Just want to establish that before hand before we dive into this, so that you know it could be a problem that's related to your ISP, not your computer or the Riot servers.

There was a known issue with a particular version of Mac OS, and Riot's solution is for you to update your OS. I think it was Yosemite, though I don't know it off by heart.

If you can't/don't want to update your OS, you can try [changing your DNS](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues#mq3). Many people have reported that it worked for them, so if you haven't already, give it a go.

Best of luck!
I have the most recent OS X and what happens if I change my DNS what will it achieve?

Well, Domain Name Server is what retrieves names for the things you access on the internet. Kinda like a contacts list, it changes a port number to an actual address that it can receive data from. When you get internet, your internet adapter will use the ISPs default DNS server, whatever it may be. Some ISPs, such as TPG, are known to have bad DNSes, so it's suggested that you change it.

Of course, though, your ISP will always presume that you're using the default DNS, and track your stats from that. Things such as data metering and usage might stop working if you change DNS, and that's why you're told to remember your previous settings so that you can easily change back.

If you've "tried everything under the Sun", then I think it's worth giving this a shot, at least.

> [{quoted}](name=HORSE OF FORCE,realm=OCE,application-id=ElA0rvVL,discussion-id=su3Egexj,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2015-02-18T23:20:53.689+0000)
>
> Well, Domain Name Server is what retrieves names for the things you access on the internet. Kinda like a contacts list, it changes a port number to an actual address that it can receive data from. When you get internet, your internet adapter will use the ISPs default DNS server, whatever it may be. Some ISPs, such as TPG, are known to have bad DNSes, so it's suggested that you change it.
> 
> Of course, though, your ISP will always presume that you're using the default DNS, and track your stats from that. Things such as data metering and usage might stop working if you change DNS, and that's why you're told to remember your previous settings so that you can easily change back.
> 
> If you've "tried everything under the Sun", then I think it's worth giving this a shot, at least.

It's finally worked it took a day or two after changing the DNS and I was just about to give up but it finally worked so thank you

A day or two? Did you forget to flush your DNS cache? :P

But anyway, good to hear that it's working for you. That's what I'm here for. If you run into any further problems, don't be afraid to ask again!
